guide.introduction: Here's how to make a toy boat automata that is very sweet and interesting. I often have it on the coffee table when I have guests, and it's surprising how often it's picked up and played with by young and old.
guide.introduction_rendered:
Here's how to make a toy boat automata that is very sweet and interesting. I often have it on the coffee table when I have guests, and it's surprising how often it's picked up and played with by young and old.

Relevant parts
  • Assorted hardwoods or softwoods
  • Number 4 washers
  • 1/8" brass or wood dowel
  • Glue
Tools
  • Drill
  • Sander
  • Scroll saw, band saw, or jigsaw
  • Table saw or hand saw

lines.text: First, save the layout and print the patterns.
lines.text_raw: First, save the layout and print the patterns.

lines.text: Next, you can either cut out the patterns and glue them to the wood, or you can trace them onto the wood; whatever floats your boat. I used a 1/4"-thick piece of oak board for the box and waves and a 1/4"-thick piece of mahogany for the boat and crank. The sails are about 1/8" thick, also made of oak.
lines.text_raw: Next, you can either cut out the patterns and glue them to the wood, or you can trace them onto the wood; whatever floats your boat. I used a 1/4"-thick piece of oak board for the box and waves and a 1/4"-thick piece of mahogany for the boat and crank. The sails are about 1/8" thick, also made of oak.

lines.text: You don't have to use hardwood for this project. Whatever you can find will work.
lines.text_raw: You don't have to use hardwood for this project. Whatever you can find will work.

lines.text: I used a 1/4-inch piece of mahogany for the boat. I also cut an extra piece for the cabin. This is not necessary; you can just add a cabin onto the pattern. I did it for the 3-D effect.
lines.text_raw: I used a 1/4-inch piece of mahogany for the boat. I also cut an extra piece for the cabin. This is not necessary; you can just add a cabin onto the pattern. I did it for the 3-D effect.

lines.text: Now draw where your masts will go.
lines.text_raw: Now draw where your masts will go.

lines.text: When drilling blind holes, a good trick is to put a piece of tape on the drill bit to know how deep to go. I drilled a hole for the masts with a 1/8" drill bit, and for the back pinion pin hole I used a 5/32" drill bit.
lines.text_raw: When drilling blind holes, a good trick is to put a piece of tape on the drill bit to know how deep to go. I drilled a hole for the masts with a 1/8" drill bit, and for the back pinion pin hole I used a 5/32" drill bit.

lines.text: Next, draw out where the cabin/cannon windows will be and use a 1/16" drill bit to slightly etch them into the wood.
lines.text_raw: Next, draw out where the cabin/cannon windows will be and use a 1/16" drill bit to slightly etch them into the wood.

lines.text: Next, cut out your sails. I used 1/8-inch oak. Then I cut my masts, sanded one side for better glue adhesion and used clothes pins to hold them until the glue had hardened.
lines.text_raw: Next, cut out your sails. I used 1/8-inch oak. Then I cut my masts, sanded one side for better glue adhesion and used clothes pins to hold them until the glue had hardened.

lines.text: After they have dried, glue them to your boat.
lines.text_raw: After they have dried, glue them to your boat.

lines.text: I used a permanent felt marker to mark the cabin/cannon windows and the flag.
lines.text_raw: I used a permanent felt marker to mark the cabin/cannon windows and the flag.

lines.text: Next, I used a 1/8 inch drill bit to drill the pinion and crank holes for the outside of the toy. A good way to do this is to clamp both together and drill them at the same time so that they line up perfectly.  I also drilled the inside waves and boat, but I used a 5/32" drill bit so the waves move smoothly.
lines.text_raw: Next, I used a 1/8 inch drill bit to drill the pinion and crank holes for the outside of the toy. A good way to do this is to clamp both together and drill them at the same time so that they line up perfectly.  I also drilled the inside waves and boat, but I used a 5/32" drill bit so the waves move smoothly.

lines.text: Now paint the inside parts of the toy. I used Tung'n Teak Danish oil.
lines.text_raw: Now paint the inside parts of the toy. I used Tung'n Teak Danish oil.

lines.text: Start putting your box together. I made the sides of the box 1" X 1¼" with a tapered inside slope so it wouldn't interfere with the movement of the waves. I also glued in the fixed pinion rod. I used a piece of 1/8" brass. You can also use 1/8" wood dowel.
lines.text_raw: Start putting your box together. I made the sides of the box 1" X 1¼" with a tapered inside slope so it wouldn't interfere with the movement of the waves. I also glued in the fixed pinion rod. I used a piece of 1/8" brass. You can also use 1/8" wood dowel.

lines.text: Start putting your project together. I used #4 washers for spacers, but this is not necessary. Your boat and waves should move freely since these holes are drilled with a 5/32" drill bit.
lines.text_raw: Start putting your project together. I used #4 washers for spacers, but this is not necessary. Your boat and waves should move freely since these holes are drilled with a 5/32" drill bit.

lines.text: Next, cut yourself a piece of broom handle that is 1" round with a 20-degree angle on each end.
lines.text_raw: Next, cut yourself a piece of broom handle that is 1" round with a 20-degree angle on each end.

lines.text: Put your broomstick flat on the work bench and drill a 1/8" hole straight through it, off to the side.
lines.text_raw: Put your broomstick flat on the work bench and drill a 1/8" hole straight through it, off to the side.

lines.text: I used a 1/8" piece of brass dowel 1 7/8" long for the crank shaft and glued it in.
lines.text_raw: I used a 1/8" piece of brass dowel 1 7/8" long for the crank shaft and glued it in.

lines.text: Next, put it through the crank hole in the box with washers as shown.
lines.text_raw: Next, put it through the crank hole in the box with washers as shown.

lines.text: Next, glue the box together and let it dry. Then grind down the pinion dowel flush with the wood and one side of the crank, and sand the box.
lines.text_raw: Next, glue the box together and let it dry. Then grind down the pinion dowel flush with the wood and one side of the crank, and sand the box.

lines.text: Make your crank handle. I used mahogany for the crank and a piece of brass dowel for the handle.
lines.text_raw: Make your crank handle. I used mahogany for the crank and a piece of brass dowel for the handle.

lines.text: Glue the handle pin and paint the crank.
lines.text_raw: Glue the handle pin and paint the crank.

lines.text: Hope you and yours have hours of enjoyment with this simple and fun toy, suitable for all ages.
lines.text_raw: Hope you and yours have hours of enjoyment with this simple and fun toy, suitable for all ages.
